Third best technique: Lateral synthesis A third technique that could be helpful in expanding our product line is lateral synthesis. This involves combining prompts in unexpected or unconventional ways, in order to spark new and innovative thinking. For example, we might use this technique to brainstorm a list of "what if" scenarios that would challenge our assumptions about what products and product categories are likely to be successful, such as "what if we combined elements from different product categories to create a new product?", or "what if we marketed our products to a completely different audience?". By synthesizing prompts in this way, we can generate ideas that are more creative and innovative, and that have the potential to disrupt the traditional product development and marketing model. Payoff matrix: In order to determine the optimal solution for expanding our product line, we can use a payoff matrix to weigh the pros and cons of each technique. In this case, the payoff matrix might look something like this: | Technique | Pros | Cons | | --- | --- | --- | | Causal synthesis | Generates ideas and strategies that are more targeted and effective
Better meets the needs and preferences of our target market
